description: Early 17th cent., borrowed from Latin castīgātus, past participle of castīgō (“I reprove”), from castus (“pure, chaste”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱes- (“cut”). Doublet of chastise and chasten, taken through Old French. See also chaste.

verbs.description: castigate (third-person singular simple present castigates, present participle castigating, simple past and past participle castigated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, formal) To punish or reprimand someone severely.
examples: Perhaps disarmed by his own scandalous behaviour with Bathsheba, he was in no position to castigate his son for a similar fault.

entries.meaning: (transitive, formal) To execrate or condemn something in a harsh manner, especially by public criticism.
examples: But despite all this, for Barkan, the universalist notion of an 'Ottoman feudalism' was anathema: he castigated this idea as the concentrated expression of the anti-Ottomanism of the Kemalist Enlightenment.

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To revise or make corrections to a publication.
